The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title. Stock purchase arrangements are addressed in the Act. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" addresses stock purchase arrangements, defining it as an employer-maintained arrangement transferring stock to employees through stock options. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" amends section 3 of the Act to deem stock purchase arrangements as employee welfare benefit plans for specific purposes. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" deems stock purchase arrangements as employee welfare benefit plans for specific purposes under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" categorizes stock purchase arrangements as employee welfare benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Section 414 outlines that stock purchase arrangements must meet specific requirements to avoid being considered a violation of the Act. These requirements include granting options only to employees of the employer corporation or its parent or subsidiary corporation. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" categorizes stock purchase arrangements as employee welfare benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Section 414 outlines specific requirements for stock options, including that options can only be exercised by employees of the employer corporation, its parent or subsidiary corporation. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" categorizes stock purchase arrangements as employee welfare benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Section 414 outlines requirements for stock options, including approval by the board of directors, exclusion of larger shareholders, and compliance with ownership rules. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" categorizes stock purchase arrangements as employee welfare benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Section 414 outlines requirements for stock options, including approval by the board of directors, exclusion of larger shareholders, and compliance with ownership rules. In determining stock ownership for employees, stock purchased under outstanding options is considered owned by the employee. Participation in such options must be granted to at least 50% of all employees of the employer corporation and its parent or subsidiary corporations. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" requires that all employees granted stock options have uniform rights and privileges. Certain individuals, such as those employed less than 2 years, working 20 hours or less per week, employed for not more than 5 months in a year, or not U.S. citizens or lawful residents, are excluded from this requirement. The "Wealth Through the Workplace Act of 1999" mandates that stock options granted to employees must have uniform rights and privileges. The options must be based on the employee's total compensation or regular rate of compensation, with a maximum purchase limit set. The option price must be at least 85% of the stock's fair market value at the time of grant or exercise. The stock options granted to employees must have uniform rights and privileges, based on total compensation or regular rate of compensation. The options must be exercisable only by the employee during their lifetime and not transferable except by will or laws of descent. The stock class must be publicly traded on an SEC-regulated exchange, and the grant of options should not result in a reduction in cash compensation. The issuance or assumption of stock options in corporate reorganizations is defined as substituting or assuming options in mergers, acquisitions, or liquidations, with specific valuation criteria. The issuance or assumption of stock options in corporate reorganizations involves substituting or assuming options in mergers, acquisitions, or liquidations, with specific valuation criteria. The new option or assumption of the old option must not provide additional benefits to the employee beyond what was available under the old option. Ownership of stock is attributed to the employee based on relationships with siblings, spouse, and ancestors for percentage limitations. Ownership of stock options in corporate reorganizations is determined based on relationships with siblings, spouse, ancestors, and lineal descendants. Stock owned by corporations, partnerships, estates, or trusts is considered proportionately owned by shareholders, partners, or beneficiaries. The term "parent corporation" refers to any corporation in an unbroken chain ending with the employer corporation where each corporation, except the employer, owns 50% or more of the voting power in another corporation in the chain. Ownership of stock options in corporate reorganizations is determined based on relationships with siblings, spouse, ancestors, and lineal descendants. The term "subsidiary corporation" refers to any corporation in an unbroken chain beginning with the employer corporation where each corporation, except the last one, owns 50% or more of the total combined voting power in another corporation in the chain. The section discusses the modification, extension, or renewal of stock options, considering them as granting a new option. It also addresses the special rules for the transfer of stock after such modifications, with the fair market value determined at the time of the original granting of the option. The section defines modification as any change in the terms of the stock option that provides additional benefits to the employee, excluding certain specific changes. The section outlines provisions for accelerating the exercise of options, director or stockholder approval, and limited effect on tax provisions. A conforming amendment is made to the table of contents. SEC. 4. NOTICE REQUIREMENT.

    (a) Section 105 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to require employers to provide annual descriptions of stock disclosure statements to employees with stock purchase options.
    (b) A penalty of $100 a day is imposed for noncompliance with the disclosure requirement. SEC. 5. TREATMENT UNDER INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1986. Section 421 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new rules for stock options under Section 414(b) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. This amendment allows for deductions to be made by corporations in certain circumstances. The Income Security Act of 1974 outlines rules for stock options under Section 414(b). If an individual disposes of a share within 2 years of the option grant or 1 year after transfer, any income increase from the disposition is treated as income in the year of disposal. There is a limitation on employer deductions if shares are transferred to an individual and not disposed of. The deduction allowed under section 162(a) for corporations in subsection (a)(2) is limited if shares are not disposed of in a way that applies to paragraph (2). The fair market value of the share at the time of exercise must exceed the value at the time of grant. References to section 423 in subsection (c) are considered as references to section 414(b) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The amendments made by this Act will apply to options offered on or after January 1, 2000.
